qas.question: Along with the present, what was a verb tense in Old English?
What were the three moods that caused verb variation in Old English?
Along with the first and second, what person influenced verb variation in Old English?
What is an example of a suffix used by Old English weak verbs?
How did Old English strong verbs express the past tense?
What does modern English use to express verbal aspects?
What forms the past tense in Modern English?
What no longer indicates the past tense of weak verbs?

context: The form of the verb varies with person (first, second and <a2_0>third<a2_0/>), number (singular and plural), tense (present and <a0_0>past<a0_0/>), and mood (<a1_0>indicative, subjunctive and imperative<a1_0/>). Old English also sometimes uses <b5_0>compound constructions<b5_0/> to express other verbal aspects, the future and the passive voice; in these we see the beginnings of the compound tenses of Modern English. Old English verbs include <b6_0>strong verbs<b6_0/>, which form the past tense by <a4_0>altering the root vowel<a4_0/>, and weak verbs, which use a suffix such as <a3_0>-de<a3_0/>. As in Modern English, and peculiar to the Germanic languages, the verbs formed two great classes: weak (regular), and strong (irregular). Like today, Old English had fewer strong verbs, and many of these have over time decayed into weak forms. Then, as now, <b7_0>dental suffixes<b7_0/> indicated the past tense of the weak verbs, as in work and worked.
